statement:
Suppose $X$ is a topological space whose topology is induced by a metric
$d$, and suppose $Y\subseteq X$ is a subset. Then the subspace topology
in $Y$ is the same as the metric topology when by $d$ restricted to $Y$.

Let $d'\colon Y\colon Y\to {\mathbb{R}}$ be the restriction of $d$ to
$Y$, and let $$\begin{aligned}
   B_r(x) &=& \{ z\in X: d'(z,x)<r \}, \\
   B'_r(x) &=& \{ z\in Y: d'(z,x)<r\}.\end{aligned}$$ The proof rests on
the identity $$B'_r(x)=Y\cap B_r(x), \quad x\in Y, r>0.$$ Suppose
$A\subseteq Y$ is open in the subspace topology of $Y$, then $A=Y\cap V$
for some open $V\subseteq X$. Since $V$ is open in $X$,
$$V=\cup \{ B_{r_i}(x_i) : i=1,2, \ldots \}$$ for some $r_i>0$,
$x_i\in X$, and $$\begin{aligned}
  A&=&\cup \{ Y\cap B_{r_i}(x_i) : i=1,2, \ldots \} \\
    &=&\cup \{ B'_{r_i}(x_i) : i=1,2, \ldots \}.\end{aligned}$$ Thus $A$
is open also in the metric topology of $d'$. The converse direction is
proven similarly.
names: subspace topology in a metric space
